abstract.para: The High Court has held that clear words are required to exclude, reduce or postpone the right of subrogation.

section1.title: Summary
section1.para: The High Court has held that clear words are required to exclude, reduce or postpone the right of subrogation.

section1.title: Facts
section1.para: OMNIA provided mutual marine insurance to its members. It arranged for a bank to guarantee a member's liability to third parties, secured by bonds from the claimants for a fee. OMNIA subsequently granted the bank a fixed charge over its book debts as a continuing security for its liabilities to the bank, until provisional liquidators of OMNIA were appointed. The bank appointed receivers under its charge.

Each bond stated that it was "separate from any other security or right of indemnity taken in respect of the guarantee from any person, including your above named customer". The claimants argued that on payment in full of any particular bond, they were entitled to be subrogated to the rights of the bank to the security from OMNIA. The bank argued that even assuming that such a right would normally arise, it was excluded in this case by the terms of the bond.

section1.title: Decision
section1.para: The court held that clear words were required to exclude, reduce or postpone the right of subrogation. The requirement to keep the bond separate from any other security appeared to be sufficient to cover the position before it had been discharged but not to rights arising after and in consequence of its payment in full. The Vice Chancellor accepted that it was not clear what the draftsman had in mind when inserting the provision, but that the uncertainty could not be converted into the clear words which, in his view, were required to give rise to the exclusion of postponement.

para.emphasis: Liberty Mutual Insurance Co (UK) Limited v HSBC Bank PLC [2001] ALL ER (D) 72.
